'Sodium silicate' is the common name for a compound sodium metasilicate,
Na 2SiO 3, also known as 'waterglass' or 'liquid glass'. It
is available in aqueous solution and in solid form and is used in cements,
passive fire protection, refractories, textile and lumber processing, and
automobiles. Sodium carbonate and silicon dioxide react when molten to form
sodium silicate and carbon dioxide:
:Na 2CO 3 + SiO 2 â Na 2SiO 3
+ CO 2 Anhydrous sodium silicate contains a chain polymeric anion
composed of corner shared {SiO 4} tetrahedral, and not a discrete
SiO 32â  ion. In addition to the
anhydrous form, there are hydrates with the formula
Na 2SiO 3Â·nH 2O (where n = 5, 6, 8, 9) which
contain the discrete, approximately tetrahedral anion
SiO 2(OH) 22â with water of hydration. For
example, the commercially available sodium silicate pentahydrate
Na 2SiO 3Â·5H 2O is formulated as
Na 2SiO 2(OH) 2Â·4H 2O and the
nonahydrate Na 2SiO 3Â·9H 2O is formulated as
Na 2SiO 2(OH) 2Â·8H 2O. Wells A.F.
(1984) Structural Inorganic Chemistry 5th edition Oxford Science Publications
ISBN 0-19-855370-6

In industry, the various grades of sodium silicate are characterized by their
SiO 2:Na 2O ratio, which can vary between 2:1 and
3.75:1. Ashford's Dictionary of Industrial Chemicals, third edition, 2011,
page 8369 Grades with this ratio below 2.85:1 are termed 'alkaline'. Those
with a higher SiO 2:Na 2O ratio are described as 'neutral'.
